title: A TUTORIAL ON BROWNIAN MOTION FOR BIOSTATISTICIANS
abstract: This manuscript provides an in-depth exploration of Brownian Motion, a fundamental stochastic process in probability theory for Biostatisticians. It begins with foundational definitions and properties, including the construction of Brownian motion and its Markovian characteristics. The document delves into advanced topics such as the Karhunen-Loève expansion, reflection principles, and Lévy's modulus of continuity. Through rigorous proofs and theorems, the manuscript examines the non-differentiability of Brownian paths, the behavior of zero sets, and the significance of local time. The notes also cover important results like Donsker's theorem and Blumenthal's 0-1 law, emphasizing their implications in the study of stochastic processes.

sections.title: 1 Introduction
sections.content:
Brownian motion, also known as Wiener process, is one of the most important and widely studied stochastic processes in both probability theory and mathematical physics. Originally observed in the erratic movement of pollen grains suspended in water by the botanist Robert Brown, it was later rigorously formalized by Norbert Wiener in the early 20th century. Brownian motion serves as a cornerstone in the modeling of various random phenomena, ranging from financial markets to the diffusion of particles in fluids.
This manuscript provides a comprehensive overview of the key concepts, properties, and applications of Brownian motion. The exploration begins with a formal definition of Brownian motion and its fundamental properties, such as stationary independent increments and the Gaussian distribution of the process. Following the foundational aspects, the document delves into more advanced topics, including the Karhunen-Loève expansion, which decomposes a process with zero mean and finite variance into an orthonormal basis, and the reflection principle, which is a crucial result derived from the strong Markov property.
Furthermore, the manuscript covers the non-differentiability of Brownian paths, illustrating the unique and sometimes counterintuitive nature of the process. The analysis of zero sets and local time provides deeper insights into the structure of paths and their occupation measures. Additionally, important theorems such as Blumenthal's 0-1 law, Donsker's theorem, and Lévy's characterization are discussed, each highlighting critical aspects of stochastic processes and their implications in various fields.
Overall, these notes aim to equip the reader with a solid understanding of Brownian motion, from its theoretical underpinnings to its practical applications in modern science and engineering.

sections.title: 2.1 Brownian Motion
sections.content:
Definition 1 (Standard Brownian Motion (Liggett, 2010)). Standard Brownian Motion B(t) is a stochastic process with continuous paths that satisfies one of the following properties:
(a) B(t) has stationary independent increments, and B(t) is N(0, t) for t ≥ 0.
(b) B(t) is a Gaussian process with EB(t) = 0 and
Cov(B(s), B(t)) = s ^t.
Remarks:
• Sometimes we write Bt for B(t) and Bt(w) or B(t, w) for a given sample point w ∈ Ω.
• There exists a probability space (Ω, Η, P) on which standard Brownian motion B exists. The proof is postponed to Theorem 1.
It is convenient to take Ω = C[0, ∞), the space of all continuous functions w(·) on R+ or [0, ∞). Note that if we simply take Ω = R[0,∞) and its Borel o-algebra, then the set
C = {w : B(t,w) is continuous in t.}
is not even an event since it depends on uncountably many points. For Ω = C[0,∞), the σ-algebra is taken to be the Borel σ-algebra, i.e., the smallest one for which the projection mapping w → w(t) is measurable for each t and we denote it as H. We have a family P = {P*} of probability measures indexed by x ∈ R¹ instead of a single probability measure. The measure P is the distribution of x + B(·) where B is a standard Brownian motion. The corresponding expectation is denoted by Ex. The probability triple is denoted by (Ω, H, P*). If in addition, we have a filtration F = {Ft : t > 0}, then the stochastic basis is the quadruple (Ω, H, F, P˚) (Dabrowska, 2020).
Lemma 1. Let Ω = R[0,∞) and H be its Borel o-algebra. Then the set
C = {w : B(t,w) is continuous in t.}
is not even an event, i.e., C ∉ H.
Proof. Define property (*): ∃J countable s.t. if f ∈ A, g ∈ R[0,∞), then f|j = g|j implies g ∈ A. Define the family of sets
A = {A ⊆ R[0,∞) : A satisfies (*).}
Clearly Ba = πα¹(B(Rº)), is a subset of A (a finite and πα is the projection from R[0,∞) to Rº). But H is generated from Ba:
H = σ (∪a finite πα¹(B(Rº))).
So if we can show that A is a σ-algebra and C ∉ A, then we are done. C does not satisfy (*): if J exists, we pick x ∈ J and set g(x) = f(x) + 1; then f|j = g|j but g is not continuous.

sections.title: 3.1 Existence and Construction
3.2 The Markov and Strong Markov Property
sections.content:
Define two σ-algebras:
$\begin{aligned}
F_s &= \sigma(B_r : r \le s) \\ 
F_+ &= \bigcap_{t>s}F_t
\end{aligned}
$
Let f (u) > 0 for all u > 0, then the random variable
$\limsup_{t \downarrow s} \frac{B_t-B_s}{f(t-s)} \in \mathcal{F}_s$
but is not $\mathcal{F}_s^+$measurable since it depends on the value of $B_t$. The $\sigma$-algebra $\mathcal{F}_s^+$ can be considered as “an infinitesimal peak” at the future (Durrett, 2019).
Theorem 2 (Markov Property). If Y is bounded and measurable, then for every x ∈ R¹ and s ≥ 0, we have
$E^x(Y \circ \theta_s | \mathcal{F}_s^+) = E^{B(s)} Y$ a.s. $P^x$

sections.title: 3.3 Karhunen-Loéve Expansion
sections.content:
Theorem 4 (Karhunen-Loéve (Dabrowska, 2020)). If {Xt : t ∈ [0, 1]} is a process with zero mean and finite variance, then it admits a decomposition
$X_t = \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} Y_n\varphi_n(t),$
where Yn's are pairwise uncorrelated random variables and φn's form an orthonormal basis in L²([0, 1]) determined by K(s,t) = Cov(Xs, Xt), the covariance of the process.
Remarks: If K(s,t) is a positive definite kernel and the associated eigenfunctions form a complete orthonormal sequence of L²([0, 1]), then we can take Yn = ⟨X, φn⟩ where φn's are eigenfunctions of K. In this case, Yn's are uncorrelated mean zero variables with variance λn, the eigenvalues of K(s, t).
Example 1 (Brownian Motion on the unit interval). Standard Brownian Motion on [0, 1] has covariance K(s,t) = s^t and can be decomposed as
$\begin{aligned} 
K(s,t) &= \sum_{j=1}^{\infty} \lambda_j\phi_j(s)\phi_j(t) \\
\lambda_j &= \frac{4}{(2j-1)^2\pi^2} \\ 
\phi_j(t) &= \sqrt{2} \sin((\frac{i}{2} -1) \pi t) 
\end{aligned}$
Moreover, Brownian motion has the same distribution as
$W_t \sim \sum_{j=1}^{\infty} \sqrt{\lambda_j} V_j\varphi_j (t),$
where Vj, j ≥ 0 are i.i.d. N(0, 1) variables. The derivation of φj boils down to solving differential equations and its distribution relies on the convergence of Riemannian sum.

sections.title: 4.2 Zero Set
sections.content:
Consider the zero set (for a given ω ∈ Ω)
Z(w) = {t ∈ R+ : Bt (w) = 0}
Theorem 7 (Zero Set). With probability 1, the set Z is perfect, and hence closed and uncountable. The Lebesgue measure of Z is 0 a.s.
Remark: A set is perfect if it is closed with no isolated points, i.e., every point is a limit point. By the Markov property, we conclude that the level set L(a, w) = {t ∈ R+ : Bt(w) = a} has the same properties as the zero set Z(w) does.
Proof. The 0 Lebesgue measure is easy to show:
$\mathbb{E}[m(Z)] = \mathbb{E}[\int_{\mathbb{R}+} I_Z(t)dt ] = \int_{\mathbb{R}+} \mathbb{E}[I_Z (t)]dt = \int_{\mathbb{R}+} P(B(t) = 0)dt = 0$
For a given w, Z = B−1({0}), i.e., the inverse image of {0} under the continuous mapping B(.,w). Hence, Z is closed and its complement is a countable union of open intervals. We write
$Z = \bigcup_{n \in \mathbb{N}} (l_n, r_n)$
and rn are stopping times but In are not.
Next, let t ∈ Z be any zero of the path, then t is either a limit point of Z from the left or not.

sections.content:

sections.title: 4.4 Reflection Principle
sections.content:
This is another application of the strong Markov property.
Theorem 9 (Reflection Principle). If a > 0 and b < a, then for any t > 0,
Pº (M(t) > a, B(t) < b) = P° (B(t) > 2a - b),
where
M(t) = max 0<s<t B(s)
is the running maximum of B up to time t.
Proof. Define
T = inf{s ≥ 0 : B(s) = a},
Ys(w) = I(s < t, B(t − s) > 2a – b) – I(s < t, B(t − s) < b).
For s < t,
EYs = Pº (B(t − s) > 2a – b) – Pº (B(t − s) < b).
By symmetry, on the set {7 < ∞}, we have
EB(T)Y, = EY, = EYs|s=t = 0.

sections.title: 4.6 Lévy's Martingale Characterization
sections.content:
Definition 2 (Predictable Variation (Dabrowska, 2020)). If M (t) is a locally square integrable martingale then M²(t) is a local sub-martingale. By Doob-Meyer's decomposition, there exists a predictable process ⟨M⟩(t) s.t. M²(t) − ⟨M⟩(t) is a local martingale. The process ⟨M⟩(t) is referred to as the predictable variation of M(t) and can be obtained as the in probability limit of sums
$\sum_{i=1}^{n} \mathbb{E} (M²(t_i) - M² (t_{i-1})|\mathcal{F}_{t_{i-1}} ) = \sum_{i=1}^{n} Var (M(t_i) - M(t_{i-1})|\mathcal{F}_{t_{i-1}}),$
where 0 = to < t1 < … < tk = t is a partition with mesh maxi ti-ti-1 → 0.
Theorem 11 (Lévy's Characterization of B (Çinlar, 2011)). If M(t) is a continuous square integrable martingale w.r.t. F with M(0) = 0, and ⟨M⟩(t) = t, then M(t) is a standard Brownian motion w.r.t. F.
Remarks: By Doob-Meyer, the statement ⟨M⟩(t) = t is equivalent to say that M²(t) – t is again a martingale w.r.t. F.

sections.title: 4.7 Donsker's Theorem
sections.content:
In non-parametric statistics, one of the most important distributions is the empirical distribution
$F_n(t) = \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} I(X_i \le t),$
where Xi's are i.i.d. random variables with the same distribution F. By SLLN, Fn(t) converges to F(t) a.s. and the convergence is strengthened to uniform by Glivenko-Cantelli. By the classical CLT, $\sqrt{n} (F_n(t) - F(t))$ converges weakly to N(0, F(t)(1 – F(t))).
Now if we regard Fn(·) as a stochastic process indexed by t ∈ R, what can we say about the limiting distribution of {√n(Fn(t) – F(t)) : t ∈ R}? Moreover, let H be a class of measurable functions, then what can we say about the distribution of
$\mathbb{P}_n h = \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} h(X_i), h \in \mathcal{H}?$
This is the subject of the empirical process theory. Here we focus on the special case ht(Xi) = I(Xi < t).
Theorem 12 (Donsker's Theorem for Empirical Distribution). Let Xi's be i.i.d. variables with a common distribution F. Define the process
W(t) = √n (Fn(t) – F(t)), t ∈ R.
Then we have
W(·) ⇒ W(F(·)) in D(R),
where W(x) = B(x) − xB(1), x ∈ [0,1] is the Brownian Bridge (BB) process.
Remarks: D(R) is the space of right-continuous functions with left limits and is equipped with the sup-norm. The weak convergence of a stochastic process Xn to X means for every bounded continuous f, we have Ef(Xn) → Ef(X). However, in practice, one applied Kolmogorov's theorem to show the weak convergence (Billingsley, 2013).
Theorem 13 (Donsker's Theorem for Partial Sum). Let Xi's be i.i.d. with mean 0 and variance 1. Define the partial sum process
$Z_n(t) = \frac{S_{[nt]}}{\sqrt{n}}, t \in [0, 1],$
where S[nt] = ∑[nt] Xi is the partial sum. Then
Zn ⇒ B
in D[0, 1], where B is the standard Brownian motion.

sections.title: 4.8 More Examples
sections.content:
Example 2 (The Inverse Gaussian Distribution (Kahle et al., 2016)). From the reflection principle, we can derive the density of the first hitting time Ta = inf{t > 0 : B(t) = a} with a > 0:
$\mathbb{P}_{T_a} (T) = \frac{dP^0(T_a \le T)}{dT} = \frac{a}{\sqrt{2\pi T^3}} \exp(-\frac{a^2}{2T}).$
This is the density of an inverse Gaussian distribution.
Example 3 (The arcsin Law of the Last Hitting Time (Durrett, 2019)). Let L = sup{t < 1 : Bt = 0} and το = inf{t : B₁ = 0}. Then
P°(L <s) = ∫R ps(0,x)P° (το > 1 – s)dx
= ...
= $\frac{2}{\pi} arcsin(\sqrt{s}),$
where ps(0, x) is the density of N(x, s). Note L is not a stopping time because the set {L < s} depends on the future after time s.
Example 4 (Truncated First Hitting Time (Liggett, 2010)). Let
$\begin{aligned} 
\gamma_a &= inf\{t > 1 : B(t) = a\}, \\
 \tau_a &= inf\{t \ge 0 : B(t) = a\}. 
\end{aligned}$
Ya is a stopping time since the set {Ya < s} is either empty (hence belongs to every Ft) or only depends on the Brownian motion within the interval (1, s].
$\begin{aligned}  
P^0 (\gamma_a \le t) &= \int_{\mathbb{R}} p_1(0,y)P^0(\gamma_a \le t | B(1) = y) dy \\
&= \int_{\mathbb{R}} p_1(0,y) P^0(\tau_{a-y} \le t-1) dy. 
\end{aligned}$
Set a = 0 and take differentiation,
$\frac{dP^0(\gamma_0 \le t)}{dt} = \frac{1}{\pi \sqrt{t-1}}$
where p₁(0, y) is the density of N(y, 1) and
P^0 (\tau_{a-y} \le t - 1) = \int_{0}^{t-1} \frac{|a-y|}{\sqrt{2\pi s^3}} \exp(-\frac{(a - y)^2}{2s}) ds.

sections.title: 5 Conclusion
sections.content: In this manuscript, we have explored key properties and theorems related to Brownian motion. The detailed analysis included the definition, construction, and fundamental properties of Brownian motion, as well as advanced concepts such as the Markov and strong Markov properties, local time, and reflection principles. These concepts are critical for understanding the behavior of Brownian motion in stochastic processes and have applications in various fields including finance, physics, and mathematics.
